Title: N/A

reviewText: Low budget film that delivers a good story with minimal blood and gore. A lonely EMT takes home a girl he thinks got attacked and soon realizes she's a vampire. She needs blood so she soon snacks on the guy's ex-girlfriend, a couple of drug dealers, and the nasty old landlady. One night she brings home a blonde for a threesome but unfortunately in the morning he wakes up and the girl is dead because she got hungry. Needless to say he then reconsiders the relationship. Not what one consider an a-list film but not b-rated either. Nicely different and well acted. It has its dark humor moments. The viewer can enjoy the dilemma that the characters find themselves. 4 stars.

reviewText: I wasn't expecting much from the movie at first, but I found it be at once extremely funny yet filled with moments of true horror (something you don't find in a lot of 'horror' movies these days). While the bulk of the plot is predictable, it is still very enjoyable. If you don't like Jason Mewes' typical characters, all I can say is he's a bit more toned down in this one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jason Mewes is simply sexy and adorable in this movie, breaking out of his usual typecast roles of the mouthy, pervy 'Jay'.  He doesn't lose his personality, though, just adds depth to it as he finds an addict in an alley and nurses her back to "health", falling in love along the way.  On the rebound from his recent breakup with his ex, it's just what he needs to forget about her and focus on taking care of this Vampire.  It isn't long before things get out of hand, though, and he realizes he's "Bitten" off more than he can chew, so to speak!  Great B movie, highly recommended!
summary: Jay (from 'Jay and Silent Bob') takes on a New Role as Vampire Keeper/Boyfriend
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jack is a night shift paramedic. He's looking for a girlfriend to rekindle his love life. He rescues a hot girl on the brink of death from a pile of trash and drug dealers when he's on his way home one morning. She turns out to be a vampire. He's torn between kicking his new girlfriend out or putting up with it and finding a way to get her the blood she needs to survive. Can a relationship like this actually work out.This movie is pretty funny. It's totally not serious at all and has a really thin plot. If you can even call it a plot. It has an original new take on the daily life of a vampire. The bread and butter of this film is the funny situations the characters are put in and the vampire girl tits. Those 2 things, or should I say 3 things, make this movie a pretty entertaining watch.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Erica Cox is absolutely stunning in this film. The plot is thin, but her sultry looks are well worth this lightly funny, sexy vampire horror film.Jack (Jason Mewes)a paramedic finds Danika (Erica Cox) passed out near his house. He takes her in. She's been bitten. He looks after her, her vampireness begins to assert itself. She goes through a couple of options (animal, blood donor bag, etc.) but finds she can only stomach fresh warm blood. So that's what she does. That's pretty much it. There's holes in the plot such as why Jack takes her to his apartment, and not to hospital. And why he accepts her vampirism at first - probably because she's so hotDid I say Erica Cox is sexy?

reviewText: When I watched this film I thought 'oh cool!  The guy who plays Jay from all those Kevin Smith movies is in it'.  But when I finished watching this film I thought 'Oh my! This was a movie that could have been'.  It wasn't a terrible movie, there were some actual funny parts to it and some sexy scenes including Erica Cox.  Yet, the entire movie seemed to be juvinal and lacking in plot.  Furthermore, the movie seemed to be small in scope.  The actual terror and threat beyond the apartment that the characters lived in seemed to be non existant.  It just seemed to be no threat to me as an audience member.  Yet there were some moments in it I enjoyed.  Like the music from barney when he had to clean up after Erica Cox, it was kind of funny for me.  So I give it a 3 star because it was a plus and minus movie that couldn't decide what kind of movie it wanted to be.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bitten (Harvey Glazer, 2008)Glazer, producer of one of my favorite movies of 2007 (The Mad), takes the director's chair here for Bitten, a similar comedy/horror mix with a similar surprisingly-famous cast and a similarly (though not as sharp) amusing script from Tim McGregor and Tyler Levine, who previously collaborated on UKM: Ultimate Killing Machine, which I haven't yet seen. After this, though, I'm tempted to track it down.Jack (Kevin Smith regular Jason Mewes, who plays Jay in the Jay and Silent Bob movies), a lovelorn EMT, and his partner Roger (The Boondock Saints' Richard Fitzpatrick), are going about their daily lives on the graveyard shift. Jack is moaning about his ex-girlfriend Sherry (The Mad's Jordan Madley) and Roger is telling him it's time to get on with his life (in not so polite terms). So what do you think happens when Jack, on his way home from work, discovers a dying woman in an alley? EMT training and rebound attachment combine. It doesn't help matters that the woman, whose name is Danika (Erica Cox from American Pie Presents Beta House), is smokin' hot. Jack falls almost instantly, and Danika isn't averse, but there's one big problem: Danika, as it turns out, was attacked by a vampire. What do you do when you're an EMT and your new girlfriend has a taste for the red stuff?I have to say that my favorite thing about this movie is actually the interplay between Jack and Roger; it's what would have happened had Quentin Tarantino written the dialogue for Scorsese's Bringing Out the Dead: sharp, funny, and natural-sounding. Once the plot is kicked off, the dialogue is a bit less...well, that. But I really liked the pacing here, the acting is stellar for a movie of this caliber, the script is awesome, and Glazer is a competent director. I liked this one a bunch. ***
Title: N/A

reviewText: As vampire movies go, this one kind of circles the drain for the first 10-15 minutes provoking some mild curiosity  Jason Mewes' character is actually sympathetic at the start until he meets Daneka (played by Erica Cox, a babe and a one note wonder if there ever was one), opens his mouth the moment some irregularity occurs and then the expletives start flying.  Once you take all the f**k and b**ch words out of his repertoire, Mewes as an actor is pretty much worthless and ineffective.  The supporting character, Roger, is also interesting at the onset, but one too many crapper jokes send him flushing down that proverbial porcelain throne not too far later.  As for the horror-comedy itself, it neither works as a comedy by trying to use a relationship with a vampire as a spoof for rebounding, co-dependence and/or the junkie-life, nor does it work as horror since there isn't one scary moment in the whole film save for possibly when we first see Daneka left for dead in a dumpster.  Setting the majority of the movie in Jack's apartment makes for both a claustrophobic and boring movie.  She knows she is a vampire, she knows she has the power to leave and find her own food in a city full of low-lifes, so why doesn't she.  Sure, dear reader, you will have your own take on this.  Then again, some people actually find something redeemable about this film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In Bitten (2008), Jack (Jason Mewes) is a paramedic who finds an injured girl (Erica Cox) covered with blood in a trash dumpster, and takes her to his apartment for medical treatment.  The girl named Danika has lost her memory.  When Danika turns out to be a vampire in need of fresh blood, and sinks her fangs into Jack's ex- girlfriend Sherry (Jordan Madley), Jack is soon into something very deep and twisted.  Tidying up the mess, Jack tries to find a way to satisfy his new girlfriend's needs, that doesn't involve homicide, but alas only blood from a live human will do.  At work, Jack's partner Roger (Robert Fitzpatrick) notices changes in his friend, and becomes concerned when his behavior becomes more and more erratic. With bodies rising from the dead, and corpses pilling up in his apartment, Jack has doubts about the long term viability of this strange relationship.Often scantily dressed, Eric Cox makes a sexy vampire, as Danika spends most of her time in Jack's darkened apartment.  Jason Mewes gives a good performance as the conflicted and gullible Jack.  Robert Fitzpatrick steals most of the scenes he is in, with plenty of crude toilet humor, and cynical, cocksure advice.Bitten isn't particularly creative or scary, but spices things up with sex and black comedy, making entertaining viewing for fans of the popular vampire genre.
Title: N/A
